items.text: Follow Metaprompting guardrails for resonsible AI
Consider Gateway patterns with APIM  or solutions like AI central for better rate limiting, load balancing, authentication and logging
Enable monitoring for your AOAI instances

Create alerts to notify teams of events such as an entry in the activity log created by an action performed on the resource, such as regenerating its subscription keys or a metric threshold such as the number of errors exceeding 10 in an hour
Monitor token usage to prevent service disruptions due to capacity
observe metrics like processed inference tokens, generated completion tokens monitor for rate limit

Enable and configure Diagnostics for the Azure OpenAI Service. If not sufficient, consider using a gateway such as Azure API Managements in front of Azure OpenAI to log both incoming prompts and outgoing responses, where permitted
Use Infrastructure as code to deploy the Azure OpenAI Service, model deployments, and all related resources
Use Microsoft Entra Authentication with Managed Identity instead of API Key
Evaluate the performance/accuracy of the system with a known golden dataset which has the inputs and the correct answers. Leverage capabilities in PromptFlow for Evaluation.
Evaluate usage of Provisioned throughput model
Review and implement Azure AI content safety
Define and evaluate the throughput of the system based on tokens & response per minute and align with requirements

Improve latency of the system by limiting token sizes, streaming options for applications like chatbots or conversational interfaces. Streaming can enhance the perceived performance of Azure OpenAI applications by delivering responses to users in an incremental manner

Estimate elasticity demands to determine synchronous and batch request segregation based on priority. For high priority, use synchronous approach and for low priority, asynchronous batch processing with queue is preferred

Benchmark token consumption requirements based on estimated demands from consumers. Consider using the Azure OpenAI benchmarking tool to help you validate the throughput if you are using Provisioned Throughput Unit deployments

If you are using Provisioned Throughput Units (PTUs), consider deploying a token-per-minute (TPM) deployment for overflow requests. Use a gateway to route requests to the TPM deployment when the PTU limits are reached.
Choose the right model for the right task. Pick models with right tradeoff between speed, quality of response and output complexity
Have a baseline for performance without fine-tuning for knowing whether or not fine-tuning has improved model performance
Deploy multiple OAI instances across regions
Implement retry & healthchecks with Gateway pattern like APIM
Ensure having adequate quotas of TPM & RPM for the workload
Review the considerations in HAI toolkit guidance and apply those interaction practices for the slution
Deploy separate fine tuned models across regions if finetuning is employed

Regularly backup and replicate critical data to ensure data availability and recoverability in case of data loss or system failures. Leverage Azure's backup and disaster recovery services to protect your data.
Azure AI search service tiers should be choosen to have a SLA
Classify data and sensitivity, labeling with Microsoft Purview before generating the embeddings and make sure to treat the embeddings generated with same sensitivity and classification
Encrypt data used for RAG with SSE/Disk encryption with optional BYOK
Ensure TLS is enforced for data in transit across data sources, AI search used for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and LLM communication
Use RBAC to manage access to Azure OpenAI services. Assign appropriate permissions to users and restrict access based on their roles and responsibilities

Implement data encryption,  masking or redaction techniques to hide sensitive data or replace it with obfuscated values in non-production environments or when sharing data for testing or troubleshooting purposes

Utilize Azure Defender to detect and respond to security threats and set up monitoring and alerting mechanisms to identify suspicious activities or breaches. Leverage Azure Sentinel for advanced threat detection and response

Establish data retention and disposal policies to adhere to compliance regulations. Implement secure deletion methods for data that is no longer required and maintain an audit trail of data retention and disposal activities
Implement Prompt shields and groundedness detection using Content Safety
Ensure compliance with relevant data protection regulations, such as GDPR or HIPAA, by implementing privacy controls and obtaining necessary consents or permissions for data processing activities.

Educate your employees about data security best practices, the importance of handling data securely, and potential risks associated with data breaches. Encourage them to follow data security protocols diligently.
Keep production data separate from development and testing data. Only use real sensitive data in production and utilize anonymized or synthetic data in development and test environments.

If you have varying levels of data sensitivity, consider creating separate indexes for each level. For instance, you could have one index for general data and another for sensitive data, each governed by different access protocols
Take segregation a step further by placing sensitive datasets in different instances of the service. Each instance can be controlled with its own specific set of RBAC policies
Recognize that embeddings and vectors generated from sensitive information are themselves sensitive. This data should be afforded the same protective measures as the source material
Apply RBAC to th data stores having embeddings and vectors and scope access based on role's access requirements
Configure private endpoint for AI services to restrict service access within your network
Enforce strict inbound and outbound traffic control with Azure Firewall and UDRs and limit the external integration points
Implement network segmentation and access controls to restrict access to the LLM application only to authorized users and systems and prevent lateral movement
Use prompt compression tools like LLMLingua or gprtrim

Ensure that APIs and endpoints used by the LLM application are properly secured with authentication and authorization mechanisms, such as Managed identities,  API keys or OAuth, to prevent unauthorized access.
Enforce strong end user authentication mechanisms, such as multi-factor authentication, to prevent unauthorized access to the LLM application and associated network resources

Implement network monitoring tools to detect and analyze network traffic for any suspicious or malicious activities. Enable logging to capture network events and facilitate forensic analysis in case of security incidents
Conduct security audits and penetration testing to identify and address any network security weaknesses or vulnerabilities in the LLM application's network infrastructure
Azure AI Services are properly tagged for better management
Azure AI Service accounts follows organizational naming conventions
Diagnostic logs in Azure AI services resources should be enabled

Key access (local authentication) is recommended to be disabled for security.  After disabling key based access, Microsoft Entra ID becomes the only access method, which allows maintaining minimum privilege principle and granular control.

Store and manage keys securely using Azure Key Vault. Avoid hard-coding or embedding sensitive keys within your LLM application's code and retrieve them securely from Azure Key Vault using managed identities
Regularly rotate and expire keys stored in Azure Key Vault to minimize the risk of unauthorized access.
Use tiktoken to understand token sizes for token optimizations in conversational mode
Follow secure coding practices to prevent common vulnerabilities such as injection attacks, cross-site scripting (XSS), or security misconfigurations
Setup a process to regularly update and patch the LLM libraries and other system components
Adhere to Azure OpenAI or other LLMs terms of use, policies and guidance and allowed use cases
Understand difference in cost of base models and fine tuned models and token step sizes
Batch requests, where possible, to minimize the per-call overhead which can reduce overall costs. Ensure you optimize batch size
Set up a cost tracking system that monitors model usage and use that information to help inform model choices and prompt sizes
Set a maximum limit on the number of tokens per model response (max_tokens and the number of completions to generate). Optimize the size to ensure it is large enough for a valid response
Review the guidance provided on setting up AI search for Reliability
Plan and manage AI Search Vector storage

Ensure deployment of Azure OpenAI instances across your various environments, such as development, test, and production supporting lrarning & experimentation. Apply LLMOps practices to automate the lifecycle management of your GenAI applications

Evaluate usage of billing models - PAYG vs PTU. Start with PAYG and consider PTU when the usage is predictable in production since it offers dedicated memory and compute, reserved capacity, and consistent maximum latency for the specified model version
Evaluate the quality of  prompts and applications when switching between model versions
Evaluate, monitor and refine your GenAI apps for features like groundedness, relevance, accuracy, coherence and fluency
Evaluate your Azure AI Search results based on different search parameters
Look at fine tuning models as way of increasing accuracy only when you have tried other basic approaches like prompt engineering and RAG with your data
Use prompt engineering techniques to improve the accuracy of LLM responses
Red team your GenAI applications
Provide end users with scoring options for LLM responses and track these scores.

Consider Quota management practices. Use dynamic quota for certain use cases when your application can use extra capacity opportunistically or the application itself is driving the rate at which the Azure OpenAI API is called
Use Load balancer solutions like APIM based gateway for balancing load and capacity across services and regions

Follow the guidance for fine-tuning with large data files and import the data from an Azure blob store. Large files, 100 MB or larger, can become unstable when uploaded through multipart forms because the requests are atomic and can't be retried or resumed
Manage rate limits for your model deployments and monitor usage of tokens per minute (TPM) and requests per minute (RPM) for pay-as-you-go deployments
Monitor provision-managed utilization if you're using the provisioned throughput payment model
Tune content filters to minimize false positives from overly aggressive filters
Use customer-managed keys for fine-tuned models and training data that's uploaded to Azure OpenAI
Implement jailbreak risk detection to safeguard your language model deployments against prompt injection attacks
Use security controls like throttling, service isolation and gateway pattern to prevent attacks that might exhaust model usage quotas
Develop your cost model, considering prompt sizes. Understanding prompt input and response sizes and how text translates into tokens helps you create a viable cost model

Consider model pricing and capabilities when you choose models. Start with less-costly models for less-complex tasks like text generation or completion tasks and for complex tasks like language translation or content understanding, consider using more advanced models. Optimize costs while still achieving the desired application performance

Maximize Azure OpenAI price breakpoints like fine-tuning and model breakpoints like image generation to your advantage. Fine-tuning is charged per hour, use as much time as you have available per hour to improve results without slipping into the next billing period. The cost for generating 100 images is the same as the cost for 1 image
Remove unused fine-tuned models when they're no longer being consumed to avoid incurring an ongoing hosting fee
Create concise prompts that provide enough context for the model to generate a useful response. Also ensure that you optimize the limit of the response length.
Use infrastructure as code (IaC) to deploy Azure OpenAI, model deployments, and other infrastructure required for fine-tuning models
Consider using dedicated model deployments per consumer group to provide per-model usage isolation that can help prevent noisy neighbors between your consumer groups
